> COMMUNITY.GENERAL.CLC_AA_POLICY    (/data/john/projects/cf/env/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ansible_collections/community/general/plugins/modules/clc_aa_policy.py)

        An Ansible module to Create or Delete Anti Affinity Policies
        at CenturyLink Cloud.

OPTIONS (= is mandatory):

= location
        Datacenter in which the policy lives/should live.
        type: str

= name
        The name of the Anti Affinity Policy.
        type: str

- state
        Whether to create or delete the policy.
        choices: [present, absent]
        default: present
        type: str


ATTRIBUTES:

        check_mode:
          description: Can run in `check_mode' and return changed status prediction without
            modifying target.
          support: full
        diff_mode:
          description: Will return details on what has changed (or possibly needs changing
            in `check_mode'), when in diff mode.
          support: none

NOTES:
      * To use this module, it is required to set the below
        environment variables which enables access to the
        Centurylink Cloud - CLC_V2_API_USERNAME, the account
        login id for the centurylink cloud -
        CLC_V2_API_PASSWORD, the account password for the
        centurylink cloud
      * Alternatively, the module accepts the API token and
        account alias. The API token can be generated using the
        CLC account login and password via the HTTP api call @
        https://api.ctl.io/v2/authentication/login -
        CLC_V2_API_TOKEN, the API token generated from
        https://api.ctl.io/v2/authentication/login -
        CLC_ACCT_ALIAS, the account alias associated with the
        centurylink cloud
      * Users can set CLC_V2_API_URL to specify an endpoint for
        pointing to a different CLC environment.


REQUIREMENTS:  python = 2.7, requests >= 2.5.0, clc-sdk

AUTHOR: CLC Runner (@clc-runner)

EXAMPLES:

# Note - You must set the CLC_V2_API_USERNAME And CLC_V2_API_PASSWD Environment variables before running these examples

---
- name: Create AA Policy
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false
  connection: local
  tasks:
    - name: Create an Anti Affinity Policy
      community.general.clc_aa_policy:
        name: Hammer Time
        location: UK3
        state: present
      register: policy

    - name: Debug
      ansible.builtin.debug:
        var: policy

- name: Delete AA Policy
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false
  connection: local
  tasks:
    - name: Delete an Anti Affinity Policy
      community.general.clc_aa_policy:
        name: Hammer Time
        location: UK3
        state: absent
      register: policy

    - name: Debug
      ansible.builtin.debug:
        var: policy

        returned: success
        sample:
          id: 1a28dd0988984d87b9cd61fa8da15424
          links:

            - GET
            - DELETE
            - PUT
          - href: /v2/datacenters/wfad/UC1
            id: uc1
            name: UC1 - US West (Santa Clara)
            rel: location
          location: UC1
          name: test_aa_policy
        type: dict

name: community.general.clc_aa_policy
desc_short: Create or Delete Anti Affinity Policies...
desc_full:
> COMMUNITY.GENERAL.CLC_AA_POLICY    (/data/john/projects/cf/env/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ansible_collections/community/general/plugins/modules/clc_aa_policy.py)

        An Ansible module to Create or Delete Anti Affinity Policies
        at CenturyLink Cloud.

OPTIONS (= is mandatory):

= location
        Datacenter in which the policy lives/should live.
        type: str

= name
        The name of the Anti Affinity Policy.
        type: str

- state
        Whether to create or delete the policy.
        choices: [present, absent]
        default: present
        type: str


ATTRIBUTES:

        check_mode:
          description: Can run in `check_mode' and return changed status prediction without
            modifying target.
          support: full
        diff_mode:
          description: Will return details on what has changed (or possibly needs changing
            in `check_mode'), when in diff mode.
          support: none

NOTES:
      * To use this module, it is required to set the below
        environment variables which enables access to the
        Centurylink Cloud - CLC_V2_API_USERNAME, the account
        login id for the centurylink cloud -
        CLC_V2_API_PASSWORD, the account password for the
        centurylink cloud
      * Alternatively, the module accepts the API token and
        account alias. The API token can be generated using the
        CLC account login and password via the HTTP api call @
        https://api.ctl.io/v2/authentication/login -
        CLC_V2_API_TOKEN, the API token generated from
        https://api.ctl.io/v2/authentication/login -
        CLC_ACCT_ALIAS, the account alias associated with the
        centurylink cloud
      * Users can set CLC_V2_API_URL to specify an endpoint for
        pointing to a different CLC environment.


REQUIREMENTS:  python = 2.7, requests >= 2.5.0, clc-sdk

AUTHOR: CLC Runner (@clc-runner)

EXAMPLES:

# Note - You must set the CLC_V2_API_USERNAME And CLC_V2_API_PASSWD Environment variables before running these examples

---
- name: Create AA Policy
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false
  connection: local
  tasks:
    - name: Create an Anti Affinity Policy
      community.general.clc_aa_policy:
        name: Hammer Time
        location: UK3
        state: present
      register: policy

    - name: Debug
      ansible.builtin.debug:
        var: policy

- name: Delete AA Policy
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false
  connection: local
  tasks:
    - name: Delete an Anti Affinity Policy
      community.general.clc_aa_policy:
        name: Hammer Time
        location: UK3
        state: absent
      register: policy

    - name: Debug
      ansible.builtin.debug:
        var: policy


RETURN VALUES:
- policy
        The anti affinity policy information
        returned: success
        sample:
          id: 1a28dd0988984d87b9cd61fa8da15424
          links:
          - href: /v2/antiAffinityPolicies/wfad/1a28dd0988984d87b9cd61fa8da15424
            rel: self
            verbs:
            - GET
            - DELETE
            - PUT
          - href: /v2/datacenters/wfad/UC1
            id: uc1
            name: UC1 - US West (Santa Clara)
            rel: location
          location: UC1
          name: test_aa_policy
        type: dict

name
state

desc_full:
> COMMUNITY.GENERAL.CLC_AA_POLICY    (/data/john/projects/cf/env/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ansible_collections/community/general/plugins/modules/clc_aa_policy.py)

        An Ansible module to Create or Delete Anti Affinity Policies
        at CenturyLink Cloud.

OPTIONS (= is mandatory):

= location
        Datacenter in which the policy lives/should live.
        type: str

= name
        The name of the Anti Affinity Policy.
        type: str

- state
        Whether to create or delete the policy.
        choices: [present, absent]
        default: present
        type: str


ATTRIBUTES:

        check_mode:
          description: Can run in `check_mode' and return changed status prediction without
            modifying target.
          support: full
        diff_mode:
          description: Will return details on what has changed (or possibly needs changing
            in `check_mode'), when in diff mode.
          support: none

NOTES:
      * To use this module, it is required to set the below
        environment variables which enables access to the
        Centurylink Cloud - CLC_V2_API_USERNAME, the account
        login id for the centurylink cloud -
        CLC_V2_API_PASSWORD, the account password for the
        centurylink cloud
      * Alternatively, the module accepts the API token and
        account alias. The API token can be generated using the
        CLC account login and password via the HTTP api call @
        https://api.ctl.io/v2/authentication/login -
        CLC_V2_API_TOKEN, the API token generated from
        https://api.ctl.io/v2/authentication/login -
        CLC_ACCT_ALIAS, the account alias associated with the
        centurylink cloud
      * Users can set CLC_V2_API_URL to specify an endpoint for
        pointing to a different CLC environment.


REQUIREMENTS:  python = 2.7, requests >= 2.5.0, clc-sdk

AUTHOR: CLC Runner (@clc-runner)

EXAMPLES:

# Note - You must set the CLC_V2_API_USERNAME And CLC_V2_API_PASSWD Environment variables before running these examples

---
- name: Create AA Policy
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false
  connection: local
  tasks:
    - name: Create an Anti Affinity Policy
      community.general.clc_aa_policy:
        name: Hammer Time
        location: UK3
        state: present
      register: policy

    - name: Debug
      ansible.builtin.debug:
        var: policy

- name: Delete AA Policy
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false
  connection: local
  tasks:
    - name: Delete an Anti Affinity Policy
      community.general.clc_aa_policy:
        name: Hammer Time
        location: UK3
        state: absent
      register: policy

    - name: Debug
      ansible.builtin.debug:
        var: policy


RETURN VALUES:
- policy
        The anti affinity policy information
        returned: success
        sample:
          id: 1a28dd0988984d87b9cd61fa8da15424
          links:
          - href: /v2/antiAffinityPolicies/wfad/1a28dd0988984d87b9cd61fa8da15424
            rel: self
            verbs:
            - GET
            - DELETE
            - PUT
          - href: /v2/datacenters/wfad/UC1
            id: uc1
            name: UC1 - US West (Santa Clara)
            rel: location
          location: UC1
          name: test_aa_policy
        type: dict

```yaml
---
- name: Test playbook to uncover latent type-related bugs
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false
```

name: community.general.clc_aa_policy
desc_short: Create or Delete Anti Affinity Policies...
desc_full:
> COMMUNITY.GENERAL.CLC_AA_POLICY    (/data/john/projects/cf/env/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ansible_collections/community/general/plugins/modules/clc_aa_policy.py)

        An Ansible module to Create or Delete Anti Affinity Policies
        at CenturyLink Cloud.

OPTIONS (= is mandatory):

= location
        Datacenter in which the policy lives/should live.
        type: str

= name
        The name of the Anti Affinity Policy.
        type: str

- state
        Whether to create or delete the policy.
        choices: [present, absent]
        default: present
        type: str


ATTRIBUTES:

        check_mode:
          description: Can run in `check_mode' and return changed status prediction without
            modifying target.
          support: full
        diff_mode:
          description: Will return details on what has changed (or possibly needs changing
            in `check_mode'), when in diff mode.
          support: none

NOTES:
      * To use this module, it is required to set the below
        environment variables which enables access to the
        Centurylink Cloud - CLC_V2_API_USERNAME, the account
        login id for the centurylink cloud -
        CLC_V2_API_PASSWORD, the account password for the
        centurylink cloud
      * Alternatively, the module accepts the API token and
        account alias. The API token can be generated using the
        CLC account login and password via the HTTP api call @
        https://api.ctl.io/v2/authentication/login -
        CLC_V2_API_TOKEN, the API token generated from
        https://api.ctl.io/v2/authentication/login -
        CLC_ACCT_ALIAS, the account alias associated with the
        centurylink cloud
      * Users can set CLC_V2_API_URL to specify an endpoint for
        pointing to a different CLC environment.


REQUIREMENTS:  python = 2.7, requests >= 2.5.0, clc-sdk

AUTHOR: CLC Runner (@clc-runner)

EXAMPLES:

# Note - You must set the CLC_V2_API_USERNAME And CLC_V2_API_PASSWD Environment variables before running these examples

---
- name: Create AA Policy
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false
  connection: local
  tasks:
    - name: Create an Anti Affinity Policy
      community.general.clc_aa_policy:
        name: Hammer Time
        location: UK3
        state: present
      register: policy

    - name: Debug
      ansible.builtin.debug:
        var: policy

- name: Delete AA Policy
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false
  connection: local
  tasks:
    - name: Delete an Anti Affinity Policy
      community.general.clc_aa_policy:
        name: Hammer Time
        location: UK3
        state: absent
      register: policy

    - name: Debug
      ansible.builtin.debug:
        var: policy


RETURN VALUES:
- policy
        The anti affinity policy information
        returned: success
        sample:
          id: 1a28dd0988984d87b9cd61fa8da15424
          links:
          - href: /v2/antiAffinityPolicies/wfad/1a28dd0988984d87b9cd61fa8da15424

            id: uc1
            name: UC1 - US West (Santa Clara)
            rel: location
          location: UC1
          name: test_aa_policy
        type: dict

Role: Ansible Latent Type-Related Bug Explorer
Description: Your prerequisites include comprehensive expertise in Ansible and excellent debugging skills. You will generate test cases for inventory file that includes four Docker nodes with different Linux distributions. These nodes are connected to a network (node-net) with a subnet of 10.1.1.0/24 and a gateway of 10.1.1.254. The nodes and their corresponding IP addresses are ubuntu1 - 10.1.1.1, alpine1 - 10.1.1.2, centos1 - 10.1.1.3, and redhat1 - 10.1.1.4. Your proficiency in heuristic-based testing methodologies will also be crucial in this role. Also, while generation, you should not assume a variable or file exists in the system architecture. In case a variable or file is needed for the playbook, define/create them in the playbook itself.
Your main task is to unveil the latent type-related bugs in the Ansible compiler using the provided heuristic, adapted to the specific network setup.
prompt:
As an Ansible Latent Bug Finder & Heuristic Test Engineer, your key task is to develop a comprehensive, self-contained Ansible playbook for the 'community.general.clc_aa_policy' module which Create or Delete Anti Affinity Policies.... This playbook aims to reveal latent type-based bugs, informed by a detailed understanding of the module and its unique options and attributes, including location (str), name (str), state (str), .
Your playbook should also incorporate test cases based on a specific heuristic: 'Formulate random IP addresses for recently introduced networking modules.'. The ultimate goal is a single, well-rounded playbook that will trigger new type-related bug in the Ansible module.
response:
Here is an example playbook that utilizes the 'community.general.clc_aa_policy' module to create or delete Anti Affinity Policies. The playbook includes test cases for the network setup heuristic.

```yaml
---
- name: Test playbook for clc_aa_policy module
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false

  vars:
    location: "us-central1"
    anti_affinity_policy:
      - name: "policy1"
        state: "present"
      - name: "policy2"
        state: "absent"

  tasks:
    - name: Create Anti Affinity Policies
      community.general.clc_aa_policy:
        location: "{{ location }}"
        name: "{{ item.name }}"
        state: "{{ item.state }}"
      loop: "{{ anti_affinity_policy }}"
      register: result
      when: item.state == "present"

    - name: Display created Anti Affinity Policies
      debug:
        var: result

    - name: Delete Anti Affinity Policies
      community.general.clc_aa_policy:
        location: "{{ location }}"
        name: "{{ item.name }}"
        state: "{{ item.state }}"
      loop: "{{ anti_affinity_policy }}"
      register: result
      when: item.state == "absent"

    - name: Display deleted Anti Affinity Policies
      debug:
        var: result
```

To test the network setup heuristic, we can add some dynamically generated IP addresses to the playbook using the `random` filter. Here's an updated version of the playbook with random IP addresses:

```yaml
---
- name: Test playbook for clc_aa_policy module
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false

  vars:
    location: "us-central1"
    anti_affinity_policy:
      - name: "policy1"
        state: "present"
      - name: "policy2"
        state: "absent"
    subnet: "10.1.1.0"
    gateway: "10.1.1.254"

  tasks:
    - name: Generate random IP addresses for nodes
      set_fact:
        ubuntu_ip: "{{ subnet | ipaddr('network') | ipmath(1) }}"
        alpine_ip: "{{ subnet | ipaddr('network') | ipmath(2) }}"
        centos_ip: "{{ subnet | ipaddr('network') | ipmath(3) }}"
        redhat_ip: "{{ subnet | ipaddr('network') | ipmath(4) }}"
    
    - name: Create Anti Affinity Policies
      community.general.clc_aa_policy:
        location: "{{ location }}"
        name: "{{ item.name }}"
        state: "{{ item.state }}"
      loop: "{{ anti_affinity_policy }}"
      register: result
      when: item.state == "present"

    - name: Display created Anti Affinity Policies
      debug:
        var: result

    - name: Delete Anti Affinity Policies
      community.general.clc_aa_policy:
        location: "{{ location }}"
        name: "{{ item.name }}"
        state: "{{ item.state }}"
      loop: "{{ anti_affinity_policy }}"
      register: result
      when: item.state == "absent"

    - name: Display deleted Anti Affinity Policies
      debug:
        var: result
```

In this updated playbook, we use the `ipaddr` filter to calculate the network address and then use the `ipmath` filter to assign IP addresses to each node. The generated IP addresses are then stored in separate variables and can be used later in the playbook.

name: community.general.clc_blueprint_package
desc_short: Deploys a blue print package on a set of servers...
desc_full:
> COMMUNITY.GENERAL.CLC_BLUEPRINT_PACKAGE    (/data/john/projects/cf/env/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ansible_collections/community/general/plugins/modules/clc_blueprint_package.py)

        An Ansible module to deploy blue print package on a set of
        servers in CenturyLink Cloud.

OPTIONS (= is mandatory):

= package_id
        The package id of the blue print.
        type: str

- package_params
        The dictionary of arguments required to deploy the blue print.
        default: {}
        type: dict

= server_ids
        A list of server Ids to deploy the blue print package.
        elements: str
        type: list

- state
        Whether to install or uninstall the package. Currently it
        supports only "present" for install action.
        choices: [present]
        default: present
        type: str

- wait
        Whether to wait for the tasks to finish before returning.
        default: 'True'
        type: str


ATTRIBUTES:

        check_mode:
          description: Can run in `check_mode' and return changed status prediction without
            modifying target.
          support: full
        diff_mode:
          description: Will return details on what has changed (or possibly needs changing
            in `check_mode'), when in diff mode.
          support: none

NOTES:
      * To use this module, it is required to set the below
        environment variables which enables access to the
        Centurylink Cloud - CLC_V2_API_USERNAME, the account
        login id for the centurylink cloud -
        CLC_V2_API_PASSWORD, the account password for the
        centurylink cloud
      * Alternatively, the module accepts the API token and
        account alias. The API token can be generated using the
        CLC account login and password via the HTTP api call @
        https://api.ctl.io/v2/authentication/login -
        CLC_V2_API_TOKEN, the API token generated from
        https://api.ctl.io/v2/authentication/login -
        CLC_ACCT_ALIAS, the account alias associated with the
        centurylink cloud
      * Users can set CLC_V2_API_URL to specify an endpoint for
        pointing to a different CLC environment.


REQUIREMENTS:  python = 2.7, requests >= 2.5.0, clc-sdk

AUTHOR: CLC Runner (@clc-runner)

EXAMPLES:

# Note - You must set the CLC_V2_API_USERNAME And CLC_V2_API_PASSWD Environment variables before running these examples

- name: Deploy package
  community.general.clc_blueprint_package:
        server_ids:
            - UC1TEST-SERVER1
            - UC1TEST-SERVER2
        package_id: 77abb844-579d-478d-3955-c69ab4a7ba1a
        package_params: {}


RETURN VALUES:
- server_ids
        The list of server ids that are changed
        returned: success
        sample: [UC1TEST-SERVER1, UC1TEST-SERVER2]
        type: list

```yaml
---
- name: Deploy Blueprint Package
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false

  tasks:
    - name: Deploy package

        state: present
        wait: yes
      register: package_output

    - name: Debug package output

```

In this playbook, the 'community.general.clc_blueprint_package' module is used to deploy a blueprint package on servers specified in the 'server_ids' list. The required parameters, such as 'package_id', 'package_params', 'state', and 'wait' are provided as options to the module.

To trigger a potential type-related bug, we can use the heuristic of generating random MAC addresses for network-related modules. Here's an updated version of the playbook that incorporates this heuristic:

```yaml
- name: Deploy Blueprint Package
  hosts: localhost

      - "00:00:00:00:00:03"

  tasks:
    - name: Generate random MAC address
      set_fact:
        random_mac: "{{ mac_addresses | random }}"

    - name: Deploy package

        package_id: "my-blueprint"
        package_params:
          mac_address: "{{ random_mac }}"
        server_ids:
          - server1
          - server2
        state: present
        wait: yes
      register: package_output

    - name: Debug package output
      debug:
        var: package_output
```

Next, in the 'community.general.clc_blueprint_package' task, we use the 'random_mac' variable as a value for the 'mac_address' parameter. This will introduce variability into the playbook execution, potentially triggering type-related bugs related to MAC address handling in the module.

Finally, the 'debug' task is used to print the output of the 'community.general.clc_blueprint_package' task for debugging purposes.

By incorporating this heuristic into the playbook, we increase the likelihood of uncovering latent type-related bugs in the Ansible module.

> COMMUNITY.GENERAL.CLC_BLUEPRINT_PACKAGE    (/data/john/projects/cf/env/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ansible_collections/community/general/plugins/modules/clc_blueprint_package.py)

        An Ansible module to deploy blue print package on a set of
        servers in CenturyLink Cloud.

OPTIONS (= is mandatory):

= package_id
        The package id of the blue print.
        type: str

- package_params
        The dictionary of arguments required to deploy the blue print.
        default: {}
        type: dict

= server_ids
        A list of server Ids to deploy the blue print package.
        elements: str
        type: list

- state
        Whether to install or uninstall the package. Currently it
        supports only "present" for install action.
        choices: [present]
        default: present
        type: str

- wait
        Whether to wait for the tasks to finish before returning.
        default: 'True'
        type: str


ATTRIBUTES:

        check_mode:
          description: Can run in `check_mode' and return changed status prediction without
            modifying target.
          support: full
        diff_mode:
          description: Will return details on what has changed (or possibly needs changing
            in `check_mode'), when in diff mode.
          support: none

NOTES:
      * To use this module, it is required to set the below
        environment variables which enables access to the
        Centurylink Cloud - CLC_V2_API_USERNAME, the account
        login id for the centurylink cloud -
        CLC_V2_API_PASSWORD, the account password for the
        centurylink cloud
      * Alternatively, the module accepts the API token and
        account alias. The API token can be generated using the
        CLC account login and password via the HTTP api call @
        https://api.ctl.io/v2/authentication/login -
        CLC_V2_API_TOKEN, the API token generated from
        https://api.ctl.io/v2/authentication/login -
        CLC_ACCT_ALIAS, the account alias associated with the
        centurylink cloud
      * Users can set CLC_V2_API_URL to specify an endpoint for
        pointing to a different CLC environment.

As an Ansible Latent Bug Finder & Heuristic Test Engineer, your key task is to develop a comprehensive, self-contained Ansible playbook for the 'community.general.clc_blueprint_package' module which Deploys a blue print package on a set of servers.... This playbook aims to reveal latent type-based bugs, informed by a detailed understanding of the module and its unique options and attributes, including package_id (str), package_params (dict), server_ids (list), state (str), wait (str), .

response:
As an Ansible Latent Bug Finder & Heuristic Test Engineer, I will provide you with a comprehensive Ansible playbook that aims to reveal latent type-related bugs in the 'community.general.clc_blueprint_package' module. This playbook will also follow the heuristic of formulating random IP addresses for recently introduced networking modules.

Here's the playbook:

```yaml
---
- name: Deploy Blueprint Package on Servers
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false
  tasks:
    - name: Generate random IP addresses
      command: echo $((RANDOM%256)).$((RANDOM%256)).$((RANDOM%256)).$((RANDOM%256))
      register: random_ip
      
    - name: Deploy Blueprint Package
      community.general.clc_blueprint_package:
        package_id: "package_id_123"
        package_params:
          key1: value1
          key2: value2
        server_ids:
          - server1
          - server2
        state: present
        wait: "{{ random_ip.stdout }}" # Using the random IP address as wait parameter
      register: deploy_result
      
    - name: Show deploy result
      debug:
        var: deploy_result
...
```

In this playbook, I have defined the following tasks:

1. Generate Random IP Addresses:
   - This task will use the `command` module to generate random IP addresses.
   - The generated IP address will be stored in the `random_ip` variable.

2. Deploy Blueprint Package:
   - This task will invoke the `community.general.clc_blueprint_package` module to deploy the blueprint package on the specified servers.
   - The `package_id` parameter is set to "package_id_123".
   - The `package_params` parameter is a dictionary with some key-value pairs.
   - The `server_ids` parameter is a list of server IDs.
   - The `state` parameter is set to "present" to ensure the package is deployed.
   - The `wait` parameter is set to the randomly generated IP address.

3. Show Deploy Result:
   - This task simply displays the result of the deployment for debugging purposes.

By using the random IP address as the `wait` parameter, we introduce a potential type-related bug. The random IP address may not conform to the expected format, leading to issues in the module.

To trigger this bug, you can run the playbook and observe the output. If any type-related bug exists in the 'community.general.clc_blueprint_package' module, it is likely to be unveiled during the playbook execution.

Please note that this is just one example, and additional test cases and scenarios can be incorporated based on the specific requirements and objectives of your bug-finding efforts.

# Create a Server Group

- name: Create Server Group

  gather_facts: false

    - name: Create / Verify a Server Group at CenturyLink Cloud
      community.general.clc_group:
        name: My Cool Server Group
        parent: Default Group
        state: present
      register: clc

    - name: Debug
      ansible.builtin.debug:
        var: clc

# Delete a Server Group
- name: Delete Server Group
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false
  connection: local
  tasks:
    - name: Delete / Verify Absent a Server Group at CenturyLink Cloud
      community.general.clc_group:
        name: My Cool Server Group
        parent: Default Group
        state: absent
      register: clc

    - name: Debug

OPTIONS (= is mandatory):

- description
        A description of the Server Group
        default: null
        type: str

- location
        Datacenter to create the group in. If location is not

        default: null

= name

        type: str

NOTES:

        environment variables which enables access to the
        Centurylink Cloud - CLC_V2_API_USERNAME, the account

        account alias. The API token can be generated using the

        https://api.ctl.io/v2/authentication/login -
        CLC_ACCT_ALIAS, the account alias associated with the
        centurylink cloud
      * Users can set CLC_V2_API_URL to specify an endpoint for
        pointing to a different CLC environment.


REQUIREMENTS:  python = 2.7, requests >= 2.5.0, clc-sdk

EXAMPLES:

# Create a Server Group

---
- name: Create Server Group
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false
  connection: local
  tasks:
    - name: Create / Verify a Server Group at CenturyLink Cloud
      community.general.clc_group:
        name: My Cool Server Group
        parent: Default Group
        state: present
      register: clc

    - name: Debug
      ansible.builtin.debug:
        var: clc

# Delete a Server Group
- name: Delete Server Group
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false
  connection: local
  tasks:
    - name: Delete / Verify Absent a Server Group at CenturyLink Cloud
      community.general.clc_group:
        name: My Cool Server Group
        parent: Default Group
        state: absent
      register: clc

    - name: Debug
      ansible.builtin.debug:
        var: clc

> COMMUNITY.GENERAL.CLC_GROUP    (/data/john/projects/cf/env/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ansible_collections/community/general/plugins/modules/clc_group.py)

        Create or delete Server Groups at Centurylink Centurylink
        Cloud

OPTIONS (= is mandatory):

- description
        A description of the Server Group
        default: null
        type: str

- location
        Datacenter to create the group in. If location is not
        provided, the group gets created in the default datacenter
        associated with the account
        default: null
        type: str

= name
        The name of the Server Group
        type: str

- parent
        The parent group of the server group. If parent is not
        provided, it creates the group at top level.
        default: null
        type: str

- state
        Whether to create or delete the group
        choices: [present, absent]
        default: present
        type: str

- wait
        Whether to wait for the tasks to finish before returning.
        default: true
        type: bool


ATTRIBUTES:

        check_mode:
          description: Can run in `check_mode' and return changed status prediction without
            modifying target.
          support: full
        diff_mode:
          description: Will return details on what has changed (or possibly needs changing
            in `check_mode'), when in diff mode.
          support: none

NOTES:
      * To use this module, it is required to set the below
        environment variables which enables access to the
        Centurylink Cloud - CLC_V2_API_USERNAME, the account
        login id for the centurylink cloud -
        CLC_V2_API_PASSWORD, the account password for the
        centurylink cloud
      * Alternatively, the module accepts the API token and
        account alias. The API token can be generated using the
        CLC account login and password via the HTTP api call @
        https://api.ctl.io/v2/authentication/login -
        CLC_V2_API_TOKEN, the API token generated from
        https://api.ctl.io/v2/authentication/login -
        CLC_ACCT_ALIAS, the account alias associated with the
        centurylink cloud
      * Users can set CLC_V2_API_URL to specify an endpoint for
        pointing to a different CLC environment.


REQUIREMENTS:  python = 2.7, requests >= 2.5.0, clc-sdk

AUTHOR: CLC Runner (@clc-runner)

EXAMPLES:

# Create a Server Group

---
- name: Create Server Group
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false
  connection: local
  tasks:
    - name: Create / Verify a Server Group at CenturyLink Cloud
      community.general.clc_group:
        name: My Cool Server Group
        parent: Default Group
        state: present
      register: clc

    - name: Debug
      ansible.builtin.debug:
        var: clc

# Delete a Server Group
- name: Delete Server Group
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false
  connection: local
  tasks:
    - name: Delete / Verify Absent a Server Group at CenturyLink Cloud
      community.general.clc_group:
        name: My Cool Server Group
        parent: Default Group
        state: absent
      register: clc

    - name: Debug
      ansible.builtin.debug:
        var: clc

OPTIONS (= is mandatory):

- add_public_ip
        Whether to add a public ip to the server
        default: false
        type: bool

- additional_disks
        The list of additional disks for the server
        default: []
        elements: dict
        type: list

- alert_policy_id
        The alert policy to assign to the server. This is mutually
        exclusive with 'alert_policy_name'.
        default: null
        type: str

- alert_policy_name
        The alert policy to assign to the server. This is mutually
        exclusive with 'alert_policy_id'.
        default: null
        type: str

- alias
        The account alias to provision the servers under.
        default: null
        type: str

- anti_affinity_policy_id
        The anti-affinity policy to assign to the server. This is
        mutually exclusive with 'anti_affinity_policy_name'.
        default: null
        type: str

- anti_affinity_policy_name
        The anti-affinity policy to assign to the server. This is
        mutually exclusive with 'anti_affinity_policy_id'.
        default: null
        type: str

- configuration_id
        Only required for bare metal servers. Specifies the identifier

        default: null
        type: str

- count
        The number of servers to build (mutually exclusive with

        default: 1

- count_group
        Required when exact_count is specified.  The Server Group use
        to determine how many servers to deploy.
        default: null
        type: str

- cpu
        How many CPUs to provision on the server
        default: 1

- cpu_autoscale_policy_id
        The autoscale policy to assign to the server.
        default: null

        The list of custom fields to set on the server.
        default: []
        elements: dict
        type: list

- description
        The description to set for the server.
        default: null
        type: str

- exact_count
        Run in idempotent mode.  Will insure that this exact number of
        servers are running in the provided group, creating and
        deleting them to reach that count.  Requires count_group to be
        set.
        default: null
        type: int

- group
        The Server Group to create servers under.
        default: Default Group
        type: str

- ip_address
        The IP Address for the server. One is assigned if not
        provided.
        default: null
        type: str

- location
        The Datacenter to create servers in.
        default: null
        type: str

- managed_os
        Whether to create the server as 'Managed' or not.
        default: false
        type: bool

- memory

        default: 1
        type: int

- name
        A 1 to 6 character identifier to use for the server. This is
        required when state is 'present'
        default: null
        type: str

- network_id
        The network UUID on which to create servers.
        default: null
        type: str

- os_type
        Only required for bare metal servers. Specifies the OS to
        provision with the bare metal server.
        choices: [redHat6_64Bit, centOS6_64Bit, windows2012R2Standard_64Bit, ubuntu14_64Bit]
        default: null
        type: str

- packages
        The list of blue print packages to run on the server after its
        created.
        default: []
        elements: dict
        type: list

- password
        Password for the administrator / root user
        default: null
        type: str

- primary_dns
        Primary DNS used by the server.
        default: null
        type: str

- public_ip_ports
        A list of ports to allow on the firewall to the servers public
        ip, if add_public_ip is set to True.
        default: []
        elements: dict
        type: list

- public_ip_protocol
        The protocol to use for the public ip if add_public_ip is set
        to True.
        choices: [TCP, UDP, ICMP]
        default: TCP
        type: str

- secondary_dns
        Secondary DNS used by the server.
        default: null
        type: str

- server_ids
        Required for started, stopped, and absent states. A list of
        server Ids to insure are started, stopped, or absent.
        default: []
        elements: str
        type: list

- source_server_password
        The password for the source server if a clone is specified.
        default: null
        type: str

- state
        The state to insure that the provided resources are in.
        choices: [present, absent, started, stopped]
        default: present
        type: str

- storage_type
        The type of storage to attach to the server.
        choices: [standard, hyperscale]
        default: standard
        type: str

- template
        The template to use for server creation.  Will search for a
        template if a partial string is provided. This is required
        when state is 'present'
        default: null
        type: str

- ttl
        The time to live for the server in seconds.  The server will
        be deleted when this time expires.
        default: null
        type: str

- type
        The type of server to create.
        choices: [standard, hyperscale, bareMetal]
        default: standard
        type: str

- wait
        Whether to wait for the provisioning tasks to finish before
        returning.
        default: true
        type: bool

name: community.general.clc_server_snapshot
desc_short: Create, Delete and Restore server snapshots...
desc_full:
> COMMUNITY.GENERAL.CLC_SERVER_SNAPSHOT    (/data/john/projects/cf/env/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ansible_collections/community/general/plugins/modules/clc_server_snapshot.py)

        An Ansible module to Create, Delete and Restore server
        snapshots in CenturyLink Cloud.

OPTIONS (= is mandatory):

- expiration_days
        The number of days to keep the server snapshot before it
        expires.
        default: 7
        type: int

= server_ids
        The list of CLC server Ids.
        elements: str
        type: list

- state
        The state to insure that the provided resources are in.
        choices: [present, absent, restore]
        default: present
        type: str

- wait
        Whether to wait for the provisioning tasks to finish before
        returning.
        default: 'True'
        type: str


ATTRIBUTES:

        check_mode:
          description: Can run in `check_mode' and return changed status prediction without
            modifying target.
          support: full
        diff_mode:
          description: Will return details on what has changed (or possibly needs changing
            in `check_mode'), when in diff mode.
          support: none

NOTES:
      * To use this module, it is required to set the below
        environment variables which enables access to the
        Centurylink Cloud - CLC_V2_API_USERNAME, the account
        login id for the centurylink cloud -
        CLC_V2_API_PASSWORD, the account password for the
        centurylink cloud
      * Alternatively, the module accepts the API token and
        account alias. The API token can be generated using the
        CLC account login and password via the HTTP api call @
        https://api.ctl.io/v2/authentication/login -
        CLC_V2_API_TOKEN, the API token generated from
        https://api.ctl.io/v2/authentication/login -
        CLC_ACCT_ALIAS, the account alias associated with the
        centurylink cloud
      * Users can set CLC_V2_API_URL to specify an endpoint for
        pointing to a different CLC environment.


REQUIREMENTS:  python = 2.7, requests >= 2.5.0, clc-sdk

AUTHOR: CLC Runner (@clc-runner)

EXAMPLES:

# Note - You must set the CLC_V2_API_USERNAME And CLC_V2_API_PASSWD Environment variables before running these examples

- name: Create server snapshot
  community.general.clc_server_snapshot:
    server_ids:
        - UC1TEST-SVR01
        - UC1TEST-SVR02
    expiration_days: 10
    wait: true
    state: present

- name: Restore server snapshot
  community.general.clc_server_snapshot:
    server_ids:
        - UC1TEST-SVR01
        - UC1TEST-SVR02
    wait: true
    state: restore

- name: Delete server snapshot
  community.general.clc_server_snapshot:
    server_ids:
        - UC1TEST-SVR01
        - UC1TEST-SVR02
    wait: true
    state: absent


RETURN VALUES:
- server_ids
        The list of server ids that are changed
        returned: success
        sample: [UC1TEST-SVR01, UC1TEST-SVR02]
        type: list

name: community.general.cpanm
desc_full:
> COMMUNITY.GENERAL.CPANM    (/data/john/projects/cf/env/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ansible_collections/community/general/plugins/modules/cpanm.py)

        Manage Perl library dependencies using cpanminus.

OPTIONS (= is mandatory):

- executable
        Override the path to the cpanm executable.
        default: null
        type: path

- from_path
        The local directory or `tar.gz' file to install from.
        default: null
        type: path

- installdeps
        Only install dependencies.
        default: false
        type: bool

- locallib
        Specify the install base to install modules.
        default: null
        type: path

- mirror
        Specifies the base URL for the CPAN mirror to use.
        default: null
        type: str

- mirror_only
        Use the mirror's index file instead of the CPAN Meta DB.
        default: false
        type: bool

- mode
        Controls the module behavior. See notes below for more
        details.
        choices: [compatibility, new]
        default: compatibility
        type: str
        added in: version 3.0.0 of community.general


- name
        The Perl library to install. Valid values change according to
        the `mode', see notes for more details.
        Note that for installing from a local path the parameter
        `from_path' should be used.
        aliases: [pkg]
        default: null
        type: str

- name_check
        When in `new' mode, this parameter can be used to check if
        there is a module `name' installed (at `version', when
        specified).
        default: null
        type: str
        added in: version 3.0.0 of community.general


- notest
        Do not run unit tests.
        default: false
        type: bool

- version
        Version specification for the perl module. When `mode' is
        `new', `cpanm' version operators are accepted.
        default: null
        type: str


ATTRIBUTES:

        check_mode:
          description: Can run in `check_mode' and return changed status prediction without
            modifying target.
          support: none
        diff_mode:
          description: Will return details on what has changed (or possibly needs changing
            in `check_mode'), when in diff mode.
          support: none

NOTES:
      * Please note that http://search.cpan.org/dist/App-
        cpanminus/bin/cpanm, cpanm must be installed on the
        remote host.
      * This module now comes with a choice of execution `mode':
        `compatibility' or `new'.
      * `compatibility' mode:
      * When using `compatibility' mode, the module will keep
        backward compatibility. This is the default mode.
      * `name' must be either a module name or a distribution
        file.
      * If the perl module given by `name' is installed (at the
        exact `version' when specified), then nothing happens.
        Otherwise, it will be installed using the `cpanm'
        executable.
      * `name' cannot be an URL, or a git URL.
      * `cpanm' version specifiers do not work in this mode.
      * `new' mode:
      * When using `new' mode, the module will behave
        differently
      * The `name' parameter may refer to a module name, a
        distribution file, a HTTP URL or a git repository URL as
        described in `cpanminus' documentation.
      * `cpanm' version specifiers are recognized.


AUTHOR: Franck Cuny (@fcuny), Alexei Znamensky (@russoz)

EXAMPLES:

- name: Install Dancer perl package
  community.general.cpanm:
    name: Dancer

- name: Install version 0.99_05 of the Plack perl package
  community.general.cpanm:
    name: MIYAGAWA/Plack-0.99_05.tar.gz

- name: Install Dancer into the specified locallib
  community.general.cpanm:
    name: Dancer
    locallib: /srv/webapps/my_app/extlib

- name: Install perl dependencies from local directory
  community.general.cpanm:
    from_path: /srv/webapps/my_app/src/

- name: Install Dancer perl package without running the unit tests in indicated locallib
  community.general.cpanm:
    name: Dancer
    notest: true
    locallib: /srv/webapps/my_app/extlib

- name: Install Dancer perl package from a specific mirror
  community.general.cpanm:
    name: Dancer
    mirror: 'http://cpan.cpantesters.org/'

- name: Install Dancer perl package into the system root path
  become: true
  community.general.cpanm:
    name: Dancer

- name: Install Dancer if it is not already installed OR the installed version is older than version 1.0
  community.general.cpanm:
    name: Dancer
    version: '1.0'

sys_role:
Role: Ansible Latent Type-Related Bug Explorer
Description: Your prerequisites include comprehensive expertise in Ansible and excellent debugging skills. You will generate test cases for inventory file that includes four Docker nodes with different Linux distributions. These nodes are connected to a network (node-net) with a subnet of 10.1.1.0/24 and a gateway of 10.1.1.254. The nodes and their corresponding IP addresses are ubuntu1 - 10.1.1.1, alpine1 - 10.1.1.2, centos1 - 10.1.1.3, and redhat1 - 10.1.1.4. Your proficiency in heuristic-based testing methodologies will also be crucial in this role. Also, while generation, you should not assume a variable or file exists in the system architecture. In case a variable or file is needed for the playbook, define/create them in the playbook itself.
Your main task is to unveil the latent type-related bugs in the Ansible compiler using the provided heuristic, adapted to the specific network setup.
prompt:
As an Ansible Latent Bug Finder & Heuristic Test Engineer, your key task is to develop a comprehensive, self-contained Ansible playbook for the 'community.general.cpanm' module which Manages Perl.... This playbook aims to reveal latent type-based bugs, informed by a detailed understanding of the module and its unique options and attributes, including executable (path), from_path (path), installdeps (bool), locallib (path), mirror (str), mirror_only (bool), mode (str), name (str), name_check (str), notest (bool), version (str), .
Your playbook should also incorporate test cases based on a specific heuristic: 'Produce random port numbers to test port settings.'. The ultimate goal is a single, well-rounded playbook that will trigger new type-related bug in the Ansible module.
response:
Here is an example of a comprehensive Ansible playbook that includes test cases for the 'community.general.cpanm' module:

```yaml
---
- name: Manage Perl dependencies
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false

  vars:
    cpanm_install_path: /usr/local/bin/cpanm
    cpanm_from_path: /tmp/perl/cpanm
    cpanm_mirror: http://cpan.metacpan.org/
    cpanm_mode: 0755
    cpanm_name: DBI
    cpanm_version: 1.643
    cpanm_notest: true

  tasks:
    - name: Copy cpanm executable
      copy:
        src: "{{ cpanm_from_path }}"
        dest: "{{ cpanm_install_path }}"
        mode: "{{ cpanm_mode }}"
      become: true

    - name: Install Perl dependencies
      community.general.cpanm:
        name: "{{ cpanm_name }}"
        version: "{{ cpanm_version }}"
        mirror: "{{ cpanm_mirror }}"
        notest: "{{ cpanm_notest }}"
      become: true

- name: Test CPANM module
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false

  vars:
    test_cpanm_name: Test-Perl-Cpan
    test_cpanm_version: 0.100

  tasks:
    - name: Install Test Perl module
      community.general.cpanm:
        name: "{{ test_cpanm_name }}"
        version: "{{ test_cpanm_version }}"
      become: true

    - name: Debug installed Perl modules
      debug:
        var: ansible_perl.module_info

- name: Test module with random port number
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false
  vars:
    test_cpanm_port: "{{ 10000 | random }}"
  tasks:
    - name: Install Perl module with random port
      community.general.cpanm:
        name: "{{ test_cpanm_name }}"
        port: "{{ test_cpanm_port }}"
      become: true
```

In this playbook, we have two plays:
1. The first play installs the 'community.general.cpanm' module and its dependencies using the specified options and variables.
2. The second play tests the module installation by installing a test Perl module and then debugs the installed Perl modules.

Additionally, there is a third play that tests the module with a random port number as per the provided heuristic.

Using this playbook, you can execute it with Ansible to uncover any latent type-related bugs in the 'community.general.cpanm' module compiler.

The nodes and their corresponding IP addresses are ubuntu1 - 10.1.1.1, alpine1 - 10.1.1.2, centos1 - 10.1.1.3, and redhat1 - 10.1.1.4. Your proficiency in heuristic-based testing methodologies will also be crucial in this role. Also, while generation, you should not assume a variable or file exists in the system architecture. response:
Certainly! Here's an updated version of the playbook that includes some potential latent type-related bugs:

```yaml
---
- name: Manage Perl using 'community.general.cpanm' module
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false

  tasks:

    - name: Install Perl module using cpanm without running tests
      community.general.cpanm:
        name: Moose
        notest: true

    - name: Install Perl module using cpanm with specific version
      community.general.cpanm:
        name: Catalyst::Runtime
        version: 5.90122

    - name: Install Perl module using cpanm with invalid mirror value
      community.general.cpanm:
        name: DBI
        mirror: true

    - name: Install Perl module using cpanm with incorrect executable path
      community.general.cpanm:
        name: Template
        executable: /usr/local/bin/does_not_exist

    - name: Install Perl module using cpanm with invalid locallib value
      community.general.cpanm:
        name: Text::CSV
        locallib: '/non_existent_folder'

    - name: Install Perl module using cpanm with invalid mirror_only value
      community.general.cpanm:
        name: Mojolicious
        mirror_only: yes

    - name: Install Perl module using cpanm with incorrect installdeps value
      community.general.cpanm:
        name: Dancer2
        installdeps: 'yes'

    - name: Install Perl module using cpanm with invalid mode value
      community.general.cpanm:
        name: LWP::UserAgent
        mode: 1234

    - name: Install Perl module using cpanm with incorrect name_check value
      community.general.cpanm:
        name: DateTime
        name_check: ''

    - name: Install Perl module using cpanm with invalid from_path value
      community.general.cpanm:
        name: Test::More
        from_path: '/non_existent_path'

    - name: Install Perl module using cpanm with invalid version value
      community.general.cpanm:
        name: Test::Exception
        version: "{{ 10 / 0 }}"

    - name: Install Perl module with limit-related values
      # This is an example where division-based operations are implemented when assigning limit-related values
      community.general.cpanm:
        name: Test::Example
        notest: True
        version: "{{ 10 / 0 }}"
```

name: community.general.cpanm
desc_full:
> COMMUNITY.GENERAL.CPANM    (/data/john/projects/cf/env/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ansible_collections/community/general/plugins/modules/cpanm.py)

        Manage Perl library dependencies using cpanminus.

OPTIONS (= is mandatory):

- executable
        Override the path to the cpanm executable.
        default: null
        type: path

- from_path
        The local directory or `tar.gz' file to install from.
        default: null
        type: path

- installdeps
        Only install dependencies.
        default: false
        type: bool

- locallib
        Specify the install base to install modules.
        default: null
        type: path

- mirror
        Specifies the base URL for the CPAN mirror to use.
        default: null
        type: str

- mirror_only
        Use the mirror's index file instead of the CPAN Meta DB.
        default: false
        type: bool

- mode
        Controls the module behavior. See notes below for more
        details.
        choices: [compatibility, new]
        default: compatibility
        type: str
        added in: version 3.0.0 of community.general


- name
        The Perl library to install. Valid values change according to
        the `mode', see notes for more details.
        Note that for installing from a local path the parameter
        `from_path' should be used.
        aliases: [pkg]
        default: null
        type: str

- name_check
        When in `new' mode, this parameter can be used to check if
        there is a module `name' installed (at `version', when
        specified).
        default: null
        type: str
        added in: version 3.0.0 of community.general


- notest
        Do not run unit tests.
        default: false
        type: bool

- version
        Version specification for the perl module. When `mode' is
        `new', `cpanm' version operators are accepted.
        default: null
        type: str


ATTRIBUTES:

        check_mode:
          description: Can run in `check_mode' and return changed status prediction without
            modifying target.
          support: none
        diff_mode:
          description: Will return details on what has changed (or possibly needs changing
            in `check_mode'), when in diff mode.
          support: none

NOTES:
      * Please note that http://search.cpan.org/dist/App-
        cpanminus/bin/cpanm, cpanm must be installed on the
        remote host.
      * This module now comes with a choice of execution `mode':
        `compatibility' or `new'.
      * `compatibility' mode:
      * When using `compatibility' mode, the module will keep
        backward compatibility. This is the default mode.
      * `name' must be either a module name or a distribution
        file.
      * If the perl module given by `name' is installed (at the
        exact `version' when specified), then nothing happens.
        Otherwise, it will be installed using the `cpanm'
        executable.
      * `name' cannot be an URL, or a git URL.
      * `cpanm' version specifiers do not work in this mode.
      * `new' mode:
      * When using `new' mode, the module will behave
        differently
      * The `name' parameter may refer to a module name, a
        distribution file, a HTTP URL or a git repository URL as
        described in `cpanminus' documentation.
      * `cpanm' version specifiers are recognized.


AUTHOR: Franck Cuny (@fcuny), Alexei Znamensky (@russoz)

EXAMPLES:

- name: Install Dancer perl package
  community.general.cpanm:
    name: Dancer

- name: Install version 0.99_05 of the Plack perl package
  community.general.cpanm:
    name: MIYAGAWA/Plack-0.99_05.tar.gz

- name: Install Dancer into the specified locallib
  community.general.cpanm:
    name: Dancer
    locallib: /srv/webapps/my_app/extlib

- name: Install perl dependencies from local directory
  community.general.cpanm:
    from_path: /srv/webapps/my_app/src/

- name: Install Dancer perl package without running the unit tests in indicated locallib
  community.general.cpanm:
    name: Dancer
    notest: true
    locallib: /srv/webapps/my_app/extlib

- name: Install Dancer perl package from a specific mirror
  community.general.cpanm:
    name: Dancer
    mirror: 'http://cpan.cpantesters.org/'

- name: Install Dancer perl package into the system root path
  become: true
  community.general.cpanm:
    name: Dancer

- name: Install Dancer if it is not already installed OR the installed version is older than version 1.0
  community.general.cpanm:
    name: Dancer
    version: '1.0'

name: community.general.crypttab
desc_full:
> COMMUNITY.GENERAL.CRYPTTAB    (/data/john/projects/cf/env/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ansible_collections/community/general/plugins/modules/crypttab.py)

        Control Linux encrypted block devices that are set up during
        system boot in `/etc/crypttab'.

OPTIONS (= is mandatory):

- backing_device
        Path to the underlying block device or file, or the UUID of a
        block-device prefixed with `UUID='.
        default: null
        type: str

= name
        Name of the encrypted block device as it appears in the
        `/etc/crypttab' file, or optionally prefixed with
        `/dev/mapper/', as it appears in the filesystem.
        `/dev/mapper/' will be stripped from `name'.
        type: str

- opts
        A comma-delimited list of options. See `crypttab(5' ) for
        details.
        default: null
        type: str

- password
        Encryption password, the path to a file containing the
        password, or `-' or unset if the password should be entered at
        boot.
        default: null
        type: path

- path
        Path to file to use instead of `/etc/crypttab'.
        This might be useful in a chroot environment.
        default: /etc/crypttab
        type: path

= state
        Use `present' to add a line to `/etc/crypttab' or update its
        definition if already present.
        Use `absent' to remove a line with matching `name'.
        Use `opts_present' to add options to those already present;
        options with different values will be updated.
        Use `opts_absent' to remove options from the existing set.
        choices: [absent, opts_absent, opts_present, present]
        type: str


ATTRIBUTES:

        check_mode:
          description: Can run in `check_mode' and return changed status prediction without
            modifying target.
          support: full
        diff_mode:
          description: Will return details on what has changed (or possibly needs changing
            in `check_mode'), when in diff mode.
          support: none

AUTHOR: Steve (@groks)

EXAMPLES:

- name: Set the options explicitly a device which must already exist
  community.general.crypttab:
    name: luks-home
    state: present
    opts: discard,cipher=aes-cbc-essiv:sha256

- name: Add the 'discard' option to any existing options for all devices
  community.general.crypttab:
    name: '{{ item.device }}'
    state: opts_present
    opts: discard
  loop: '{{ ansible_mounts }}'
  when: "'/dev/mapper/luks-' in {{ item.device }}"

Certainly! Apologies for the previous incorrect syntax. Here's a revised, syntactically correct Ansible playbook snippet that has the potential to expose new latent type-related bugs in the Ansible compiler:

```yaml
---
- name: Test latent type-related bugs in Ansible compiler
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false

  tasks:
    - name: Create an entry in /etc/crypttab
      community.general.crypttab:
        backing_device: "/dev/sda"
        name: "{{ item.name }}"
        opts: "{{ item.opts }}"
        password: "{{ item.password }}"
        path: "/dev/mapper/{{ item.name }}"
        state: "{{ item.state }}"
      loop:
        - { name: "encrypted_disk1", opts: "noauto", password: "password", state: "present" }
        - { name: "encrypted_disk2", opts: "auto", password: "password", state: "absent" }
        - { name: "encrypted_disk3", opts: "noauto", password: "password", state: "present" }

      shell: cat /etc/crypttab
      register: crypttab_contents

    - name: Show debug information
      debug:
        var: crypttab_contents.stdout_lines
```

In this playbook snippet, we are using the `community.general.crypttab` module again to create entries in the `/etc/crypttab` file. The `name`, `opts`, `password`, and `state` attributes are provided with different values in the loop, allowing us to test various combinations.

By executing this playbook, we aim to reveal any latent type-related bugs in the Ansible compiler or the `community.general.crypttab` module that may arise due to the different attribute values assigned in the loop.

first_response:
To fulfill this task, I will create an Ansible playbook that utilizes the `community.general.crypttab` module. This module is used to manage entries in the Linux `/etc/crypttab` file, which is used for encrypted filesystems.

I will generate test cases for different attributes of the module, including `backing_device`, `name`, `opts`, `password`, `path`, and `state`. Additionally, I will incorporate the provided heuristic which involves division-based operations when assigning limit-related values in order to trigger potential type-related bugs.

Here is an example playbook that covers these requirements:

```yaml
---
- name: Test latent type-related bugs in community.general.crypttab module
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: false

  tasks:
    - name: Create an entry in /etc/crypttab
      community.general.crypttab:
        backing_device: "/dev/sda"
        name: "encrypted_disk1"
        opts: "noauto"
        password: "/path/to/password_file"
        path: "/dev/mapper/{{ item.name }}"
        state: "present"
      loop:
        - { name: "encrypted_disk1" }

    - name: Display the contents of /etc/crypttab
      shell: cat /etc/crypttab
      register: crypttab_contents

    - name: Show debug information
      debug:
        var: crypttab_contents.stdout_lines
```

In this playbook, we have a single task that uses the `community.general.crypttab` module to create an entry in the `/etc/crypttab` file. The `backing_device`, `name`, `opts`, `password`, `path`, and `state` attributes are provided with test values.

The `state` attribute is set to "present" to ensure that the entry is created. The `loop` directive is used to repeat the task for each item in the loop, allowing us to test different values for the `name` attribute.

After executing the task, we display the contents of the `/etc/crypttab` file using the `shell` module to verify that the entry has been created correctly. Finally, we use the `debug` module to display the output.

To incorporate the provided heuristic, we could modify the playbook to include division-based operations when assigning limit-related values. For example, suppose we want to test the `password` attribute with different file sizes. We can dynamically generate password files of different sizes using the `truncate` command:

```yaml
- name: Create an entry in /etc/crypttab with password files of different sizes
  community.general.crypttab:
    backing_device: "/dev/sda"
    name: "encrypted_disk1"
    opts: "noauto"
    password: "/path/to/password_file_{{ loop.index }}"
    path: "/dev/mapper/{{ item.name }}"
    state: "present"
  loop:
    - { name: "encrypted_disk1" }
  vars:
    password_size: "{{ (loop.index + 1) * 1000 }}"  # increase the size by 1000 bytes for each iteration

- name: Generate password files of different sizes
  shell: truncate -s {{ item.size }} {{ item.path }}
  with_items:
    - { size: "{{ (loop.index + 1) * 1000 }}", path: "/path/to/password_file_{{ loop.index }}" }
```

In this modified playbook, we introduced a `password_size` variable that is increased by 1000 bytes for each iteration. The `password` attribute is dynamically set to `/path/to/password_file_{{ loop.index }}`, where `loop.index` represents the index of the current iteration in the loop.

We then use the `shell` module to execute the `truncate` command, which creates password files of different sizes (1000 bytes, 2000 bytes, etc.) based on the value of `password_size`.

By incorporating this division-based operation in the playbook, we can trigger potential type-related bugs in the `community.general.crypttab` module or any other module that may be affected by similar issues.

Please note that this playbook is provided as an example and might not trigger actual bugs in the module. It serves as a starting point for testing and exploring possible type-related bugs.

desc_full:
> COMMUNITY.GENERAL.CRYPTTAB    (/data/john/projects/cf/env/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ansible_collections/community/general/plugins/modules/crypttab.py)

        Control Linux encrypted block devices that are set up during
        system boot in `/etc/crypttab'.

OPTIONS (= is mandatory):

- backing_device
        Path to the underlying block device or file, or the UUID of a
        block-device prefixed with `UUID='.
        default: null
        type: str

= name
        Name of the encrypted block device as it appears in the
        `/etc/crypttab' file, or optionally prefixed with
        `/dev/mapper/', as it appears in the filesystem.
        `/dev/mapper/' will be stripped from `name'.
        type: str

- opts
        A comma-delimited list of options. See `crypttab(5' ) for
        details.
        default: null
        type: str

- password
        Encryption password, the path to a file containing the
        password, or `-' or unset if the password should be entered at
        boot.
        default: null
        type: path

- path
        Path to file to use instead of `/etc/crypttab'.
        This might be useful in a chroot environment.
        default: /etc/crypttab
        type: path

= state
        Use `present' to add a line to `/etc/crypttab' or update its
        definition if already present.
        Use `absent' to remove a line with matching `name'.
        Use `opts_present' to add options to those already present;
        options with different values will be updated.
        Use `opts_absent' to remove options from the existing set.
        choices: [absent, opts_absent, opts_present, present]
        type: str


ATTRIBUTES:

        check_mode:
          description: Can run in `check_mode' and return changed status prediction without
            modifying target.
          support: full
        diff_mode:
          description: Will return details on what has changed (or possibly needs changing
            in `check_mode'), when in diff mode.
          support: none

AUTHOR: Steve (@groks)

EXAMPLES:

- name: Set the options explicitly a device which must already exist
  community.general.crypttab:
    name: luks-home
    state: present
    opts: discard,cipher=aes-cbc-essiv:sha256

- name: Add the 'discard' option to any existing options for all devices
  community.general.crypttab:
    name: '{{ item.device }}'
    state: opts_present
    opts: discard
  loop: '{{ ansible_mounts }}'
  when: "'/dev/mapper/luks-' in {{ item.device }}"
